reasoning: Centrality: The critique targets a meaningful sub-claim in the paper’s Section 3: that the only plausible easygoing bounded views are a narrow, implausible slice due to scale-tipping/joint aggregation issues. If overturned, it weakens an important support for “easygoingness is unlikely,” but does not by itself refute the broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion, which is also supported by the Section 2 fragility/multiplicative-target argument and by unbounded/linear arguments. Strength: It offers a plausible countermodel class (rights/threshold constraints + within-feasible-set saturating aggregation) that can avoid continuous tradeoffs that generate scale-tipping, so it does put pressure on the taxonomy and the ‘narrow slice’ rhetoric. However, it’s only sketched: it doesn’t show (i) that such theories are common/plausible under the paper’s formal assumptions (notably completeness + vNM/EU representability, which lexicographic constraints can violate), (ii) that the resulting view is genuinely “easygoing” in the paper’s sense (threshold constraints can make the target narrow in another way—must satisfy strict floors across astronomical domains), or (iii) that the paper couldn’t accommodate this as another “fussy” variant once floors are scaled. Correctness: Largely correct that hybrid threshold/rights theories exist and can be framed to block some forms of scale-tipping, and that this could expand the space of bounded views beyond the paper’s two aggregation caricatures. But it overclaims by implying this straightforwardly yields an easygoing, stable, vNM-friendly alternative; that’s contestable and not established. Clarity: The objection and proposed countermodel are understandable and fairly precise. Dead weight: Minimal. Single issue: Focused on one main structural point (taxonomy/scale-tipping), with only a small add-on about reflective stability.
title: Threshold-constrained hybrid views escape the scale-tipping dilemma
